messages: I’m Mia, your automated Medical Information Assistant from the Pediatric Mendelian Genomics Research Center (PMGRC) through Children’s National, UC Irvine, and Invitae.
I’m here to tell you all about the PMGRC study and help you decide if you want to participate.
👋 Hi Mia!
I’m going to provide details about the study like why we are doing this research, what you will be expected to do if you enroll, and possible risks and benefits.
My job is to give you plenty of information to help you choose whether or not to participate.
Great!
This chat usually takes about 30 minutes to go through before you can sign the consent form to enroll at the end.
You can always pause and come back at a later point.
At any time during our conversation, you can click the menu button (☰) at the top left to find chat options.
If you want to change any of your responses, just click on the response or go to the menu.
Okay
I understand
All of the information I will share is also described in more detail in our consent document.
You can only sign the consent form electronically after reviewing it with me or with a study team member.
You can access an example of the consent document by clicking this link, but please remember to return here to complete our chat.
Can I look at this after we chat?
Yes, you can come back here to access the link later, and I can also provide the link again at the end of the chat.
Okay, great

Whether or not you choose to participate in the study, the team at Children's National may review your interactions with me, Mia, to better understand how people interact with me and how I can improve.
Ok, sounds good
If you are ready, we can start going through the information together right now!
If you would rather review the consent later or you would rather review it with a member of the study team, just let me know!
I’d like to continue chatting with Mia now
I want to pick up this chat with Mia sometime later
I'd prefer to talk to someone from the research team
Okay!
Let’s do this!
Please be sure to take notes and write down any questions you have as we go through this chat, as you will have the option to talk to a study team member at the end. ✏️
If you have any questions that are not answered during this chat, we will put you in touch with a team member to discuss them further.
Okay! No problem.
You can use the link in your text message to come back at any time.
Let me know when you are ready to chat.
Sure thing.
Someone from our study team will contact you directly by phone or email within the next 2-3 weeks.
If you have questions now, you can contact us at PMGRC@childrensnational.org
I'm ready to chat now
Sounds good! 👍
The goal of this study is to help identify the causes of genetic health conditions.
You are being invited to join this study because you or someone in your family has a genetic health condition (or a health issue that might be related to genes).
We often enroll multiple family members (people related by blood) in the study.
Okay
Why only those related by blood?
Having genetic data from blood relatives can help us do a better job of interpreting genetic findings.
For example, if we find a genetic change in a person who has a health issue, it is important to know if this genetic change was passed down through the family.
So, having data from blood-related family members helps us interpret what we find.
Ah, that makes sense
Ideally, we would enroll the person with the genetic health condition as well as both of their biological parents (mom and dad), if possible.
So, if one or both parents are able to enroll, that would be great!
Good to know!
Each person who enrolls in the study will have to go through this study consent process.
You can enroll yourself and/or your children in this chat today, and we can send a separate chat link to any other adults who want to enroll.
Okay
For children who are 6 years old or younger, a parent or guardian can complete the consent on their behalf.
For children ages 7 to 17, (or for adults who are under another person’s legal guardianship), a parent or guardian must complete the official consent.
We will also need to talk directly to the child (if they are capable) to get their agreement about participating.
People who are age 18 or older need to go through the consent process themselves (except those who are under another person’s legal guardianship).
Okay
I understand
Can you tell me who in your family might consider enrolling in this study? (check all that apply, including any parents or other adults who might enroll)
Great!
You can complete the consent process for yourself today in this chat
Okay, thanks
If your child’s other parent or another adult family member is considering enrolling, they should also complete this consent chat themselves.
If they have not already received a link to this consent chat, I can send them one now with just a few pieces of information.
They have already received a link to this chat
I'd like to send them a link to the chat
How many of your children are you considering enrolling?
One child
More than one child
You’re welcome 😀
Now, let’s take a moment to talk a little bit about genetics.
Do you want to keep it simple or get a little more science-y?
Science-y please 🤓
Let's keep it simple
Now, let’s take a moment to talk a little bit about genetics.
Do you want to keep it simple or get a little more science-y?
Okay!
Can you tell me their name and cell phone number and/or email address?
Thank you! We’ll contact them with the information you've provided.
If you have other adult family members who are considering enrolling, please let our study team know by emailing us at PMGRC@childrensnational.org.
Okay, thanks
Okay, great
I was hoping you would say that!
You may already know that your body is made of trillions of cells.
Inside each of these cells is your DNA, which provides the instructions for how our bodies grow and develop.
Ah, okay
Your DNA is made up of a genetic code, which is represented by four letters: A, T, C and G.

A little section of the code might look something like this:

ATGCGCTAGCTCCTAGCTAGCCTAGCTAGCTAACGCTAGCCTCGTAGACTACGATCGCTAAGCTAGC
The code is actually over 3 billion letters long!
That's complicated
Okay, can you please select the ages of your children?
For your child who is under age 7 years, you will have the option to complete their consent and enrollment during our chat today.
Great, thanks!
For your child who is between age 7 and age 17, you will have the option to give your consent for your child to enroll in the study.
But because your child is over age 6, we may also need to talk to them briefly to tell them about the study.
If your child is developmentally not able to communicate, you can let us know when you talk with our study team.
Okay
So, after you complete the consent chat with me, I can help arrange a time for you (and your child) to talk to a member of our study team to finalize your child's enrollment.
That sounds good, thanks
Is your 18+ child still under your legal guardianship?
Yes
No
Individuals who are 18 years or older need to complete this consent chat themselves.
Does your 18+ child already have a unique link to this chat?
Yes
No, can we send them a link?
Sure!
Can you tell me your child's name, cell phone number, and/or email?
Thank you! We'll contact them with the information you've provided.
If you have other adult family members who are considering enrolling, please let our study team know by emailing us at PMGRC@childrensnational.org
Great, thanks!
Okay, then they will be able to use that link to complete the consent chat themselves.
Okay, thanks for letting me know
Okay
After our chat today, you will have the option to give your consent for your child to enroll in the study.
But because your child is over age 18, we may also need to talk to them briefly to tell them about the study.
Okay
So, after you complete the consent chat with me, I can help arrange a time for you (and your child) to talk to a member of our study team to finalize your child's enrollment.
If your child is developmentally not able to communicate, you can let us know when you talk with our study team.
Okay, thanks
You’re welcome 😀
I know! But your cells know how the read this code
The cells use your genetic information like a recipe book
IMAGE
It is organized into specific sections, called genes (just like a recipe book is organized into individual recipes)
This sounds familiar
Tell me more
In a recipe book, each recipe gives instructions for making a different dish
In your cells, each gene provides the instructions for molecules called RNA, and each RNA makes a different protein
IMAGE
That's interesting
These proteins can help your body to do many important things
For example, some proteins build our tissues, like muscles and nerves.  Other proteins help our bodies break down food and make energy
That's cool!
I know, right?
You have 2 copies of each gene - one from each of your parents
The 2 copies work together to make you who you are
IMAGE
Got it
People can have different versions of the same gene. This is what makes each person unique
We call these different versions of a gene “variants”
What is a variant?
Remember how we said your genes are like recipes?
Well, if there are any little typos or slight changes in the recipe, the dish might turn out differently than you expected
A variant is when the letters of the genetic code are out of order or changed in some other way
I see
When a gene has a variant it gives different instructions.
Imagine that you are baking a cake and the recipe tells you to use salt instead of sugar, or strawberries instead of chocolate!
That’s going to affect the cake!
GIF IMAGE
Got it
Okay, sounds good
You may already know that your body is made up of trillions of cells
Inside each of these cells is your DNA, which provides the instructions for our bodies to grow and develop
The DNA is arranged in sections called genes
Okay
This sounds familiar
Genes are a big part of what makes you who you are
In your cells, each gene provides the instructions for molecules called RNA, and each RNA makes a different protein
IMAGE
That's interesting
These proteins can help your body to do many important things
For example, some proteins build our tissues, like muscles and nerves.  Other proteins help our bodies break down food and make energy
Okay
That's cool!
We all have small differences in our genes, which we call "variants"
I see
When a gene has a variant it gives the body different instructions
Got it
Genetic variants are responsible for making us all unique and different
For example, things like eye color are determined by variants in our genes
Sometimes, having a certain genetic variant can lead to health issues
For example, if a person has a variant in a gene that is related to kidney health, then their chance of having kidney disease may increase.
Interesting
That makes sense
When someone has a health issue caused by a genetic change (or “variant”), we call this a genetic disorder
When we suspect that a patient has a genetic disorder, we will often do genetic testing to try and find the change (or variant) that is causing the health issue
In the PMGRC study, we are interested in doing different kinds of genetic testing to take a detailed look at people’s genetic material to look for changes that might explain their health issues
Great
Here's a 1-minute video that talks about one common type of testing, called sequencing
We are hoping to enroll patients with known or suspected genetic conditions and their blood relatives, such as parents and siblings
Can you tell me a little bit more about your history with genetic testing for you or your family member so far?
Never had genetic testing / I don't recall...
Had genetic testing
No problem
One goal for our PMGRC study is to discover new causes of health problems, like finding a new gene or new ways that differences in our genetic material can cause health problems
If genetic testing didn’t find an answer before, our research might be able to find something new
So you've had some experience. That's good!
Do you remember what the results were?
FORM
The results found something / the results didn't find anything / I don't remember
One goal for our PMGRC study is to discover new causes of health problems, like finding a new gene or new ways that differences in our genetic material can cause health problems
If genetic testing didn’t find an answer before, our research might be able to find something new
Okay...
Another goal of our study is to better understand prior genetic test results that may have been unclear
For example, if previous genetic testing found a “variant of uncertain significance”, our research might be able to help explain whether that finding is related to disease or not
Got it!
Tell me more about the different types of genetic test results?
Of course!
When genetic testing is done, we are usually looking for some genetic variant to explain the patient’s health issues.
Sometimes, the testing does find a clear answer - a genetic variant that explains the health issue.
We call this a “positive” result.
Okay
If the testing does NOT find any variants that could explain the health issue, we call this a “negative” result
Sometimes, the testing can find something that we don’t yet understand well
When a variant is found, but we aren’t sure whether it is linked to a specific health issue, we call this a “variant of uncertain significance” or VUS.
You can also check out the brief video to review the possible types of genetic results
Ah, okay
We don’t know if this kind of research genetic testing will help people get to a diagnosis, but we’re hoping that it will at least help make science and medicine better
This may help other people in the future
Well that sounds nice
We want to make sure you know that joining this PMGRC study is voluntary
What does that mean?
You can choose to be part of this study or choose not to be part of this study. And you can change your mind about being involved at any time
Whatever choice you make, the quality of care you receive will not change, and you will not lose access to your medical care or give up any of your legal rights or benefits
Also, if we make any changes to the study or if there are any important new findings, we will tell you so that you can decide if you still want to be in the study
Sounds good!
What if I am a student or employee at Children's National?
How do I let you know if I no longer want to be in the study?
You can contact the study team at any time by emailing PMGRC@childrensnational.org.
To withdraw from the study, you must send a written letter to the Principal Investigator (Seth Berger) to inform him of your decision
Sounds good!
What if I am a student or employee at Children's National?
If you are an employee or a medical or graduate student in training at Children's National, your decision to participate or not participate will not affect your employment or academic standing
Great!
How do I let you know if I no longer want to be in the study?
Participating in the study is free - so there is no cost to you or to your health insurance provider
However, if you learn something new about your health as a result of the study, you or your insurance provider will be responsible for the cost of any relevant follow-up testing or medical care
Okay
Just a little more background information for you: Dr. Seth Berger is the person responsible for this research study at Children's National. He is called the Principal Investigator.
The National Human Genome Research Institute (part of the National Institutes of Health or “NIH”) is paying for this research to be done.
Children's National and a company called Invitae are working together on this research study.
Working together - cool!
Tell me more about Invite and Children's National
Invitae is a company that provides clinical genetic testing
Children’s National is a pediatric hospital in Washington, DC.
Got it!
We are recruiting patients from all over the country, with all kinds of backgrounds and experiences with genetic testing
Makes sense
How many people will be involved?
We are hoping to enroll up to 13,000 people.
We expect half to be patients and family members referred through Children's National, and half to be from outside of Children's National
Got it
It’s really important to understand that research testing like this does not replace clinical testing.
Whether you join the PMGRC research study or not, you should always continue getting medical advice from your doctor, which might include other options for genetic testing
You might want to discuss this study with your family and anyone else you trust before making your decision
I definitely will
Who should I talk to?
Some people you could talk to about your participation in this study include your family members, your doctor, or anyone you trust to help you make decisions
Okay
So! Let’s talk about what will actually happen when someone enrolls in this PMGRC study
Yes, please!
At the end of this chat (or after talking to a study team member), if you decide that you do want to join, you will sign an electronic consent form to officially enroll as a participant.
Each participant will be assigned a unique study ID number.
This unique study ID will be used to label your study samples and data (instead of using your name or other identifying information)
That's reassuring
Once enrolled, you will be asked to provide some medical information and a detailed family health history
The medical information we collect may include things like doctors' notes, diagnoses, and past test results that may help us understand how your genetic information affects your health.
If you had previous genetic testing (such as whole genome sequencing), you may be asked to provide the data from this testing
Sounds easy enough
Where do I get my doctor's notes?
Where do I get my genetic testing data?
That’s a complicated process, but usually, it involves signing a form to send to the lab that did the original testing
Our study staff can help you take the next steps, if necessary
Okay
Where do I get my doctor's notes?
Most doctor's offices and hospitals have a “Medical Records” office or a patient portal where notes and test results can be sent directly to the patient.
Our study staff can help you take the next steps, if necessary
I see
Please be aware that the information we collect will not be provided back to you directly
Okay
Once enrolled, you may be asked to provide a tissue sample for genetic testing. This sample could be blood, saliva (spit), or cheek swab (also called “buccal swab”).
However, not every PMGRC participant will need to provide a sample
I understand
Where will my blood be drawn?
What's a buccal swab?
There are a few options
If you are having clinical blood drawn for another reason, an extra sample may be collected for this study at that time
You could also schedule a blood draw at the Children's National Clinical Research Unit (CRU)
Or our study team may be able to arrange for a mobile phlebotomy company to come to your house for a blood draw
So there are options. Got it
A “buccal swab” is a large Q-tip used for swabbing the inside of the cheeks.
If you provide a buccal sample, these will be collected either on-site at Children’s National or with a kit provided to you with instructions for collection at home and mailing back
Cool!
And that’s pretty much it! There are no other required interactions
So what happens next?
Once you’ve enrolled and provided the requested information and/or samples, a team of study investigators will review your case history and genetic results.
This team will decide what research tests will be performed on your samples and data
That's easy!
What kinds of research tests?
Your sample may be used for a variety of genetic testing including, but not limited to: Whole Genome Sequencing, Optical Mapping, and RNA sequencing.
These are different ways of looking at your genetic material
Our PMGRC study staff might contact you to request additional samples, more information, or photographs from you
What if I don’t want to provide additional samples or photographs?
You can decline these additional requests at any time and still be part of the study
Who has access to the study information?
As we mentioned before, the samples and data we gather from you will be labeled only with your unique study ID number. This means that your data and samples will be de-identified
Only a few members of the study team will be able to link your study number to your name
Other collaborators (such as Invitae or a mobile blood draw company) would only have your name and identifiers if you used that company for previous genetic testing or blood collection
That's good to know
Our PMGRC study is one of 5  Genomics Research Centers, and we collaborate with the other 4 centers.

We might share your genetic information and health information with these other experts, but any information we share will be de-identified, so these centers will not have access to your name or other personal information that directly identifies you.
This study will send de-identified data to a National Institutes of Health (NIH)-designated data repository.
This repository may be accessed by other researchers around the world
Could my information be used anywhere else?
The results of this research may be presented at scientific meetings or in scientific publications
But you will not be personally identified and no identifiable photos will be published without your separate consent
Okay, that’s good to know

Your de-identified genetic information and health information could be used for future research studies or given to another investigator for future research studies without your additional informed consent.
This de-identified information may be used for many different research studies, for many years in the future.
If you enroll in the study, you will have the option to let us know if you want to allow your samples to be used for other research beyond this study.
Otherwise, your samples will remain at the Children’s National Research Institute for use in this study only
Good to know!
So far we’ve been talking about the ways that de-identified information may be used or shared, but you might be wondering whether identifiable information will ever be shared.
Your identifiable personal information will not be given to anyone else unless you give your permission in writing first, with a few exceptions that I will explain in a moment.
The study team will be careful with the information we gather for the study, and we will only share it with authorized members of the study team or people who have a need to review this information.
Who might have a need to review the study information?
There are some third parties such as government agencies or other groups within Children's National that may check records that identify you without your permission.
They might review the study records and your medical records to make sure we are following the law and protecting the people in the study and to make sure our study results are correct.

The agencies or groups who might see these records are:
  • the Department of Health and Human Services Office of Human Research Protections
  • the National Human Genome Research Institute (part of the NIH)
  • the Children's National Hospital Institutional Review Board (the ethics board that reviewed and approved this research study)
  • the Office for the Protection of Human Subjects
Okay, that makes sense
I can provide you with a link to the Children’s National Notice of Privacy Practices at the end of our chat
Okay, thanks
You may have heard of HIPAA before, but we want to make sure you know the details and how it applies to your participation in this study
Isn’t that something I sign at my doctor’s office?
Yes, you have probably reviewed the HIPAA information at medical visits
HIPAA is a privacy law that protects your individually identifiable health information (also called “Protected Health Information” or “PHI”)
The HIPAA law also describes how information about you may be used or shared if you are in a research study.
That makes sense
Under HIPAA, you need to sign an agreement in order for researchers to use or share your PHI for research purposes.
I can provide you with a link to the Children’s National HIPAA Information Sheet at the end of our chat, and you can read the complete HIPAA authorization in the consent document
It is important that you read this carefully and ask a member of the research team to explain anything you do not understand
Can you guarantee that my information will be kept private?
We will make every effort to keep your information private, but no one's privacy can be totally guaranteed.
To help protect your privacy, the research team has obtained a Certificate of Confidentiality from the Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS)

With this Certificate, the investigators cannot be forced (for example, by a court order or subpoena) to give information that may identify you in any federal, state or local civil or criminal court, or in any administrative, legislative, or other proceedings
Good to know
What if I tell people I'm part of this study?

It is important that you know that a Certificate of Confidentiality does not stop you or a member of your family from voluntarily giving information to others about yourself or about taking part in this research

You should also know that if an insurer or employer learns about your participation and you give them permission to receive research information about you, we cannot use the Certificate of Confidentiality to keep your information private from them
This means that you must also actively protect your own privacy
Got it
Let’s talk about what types of results this research could find
Yes!
If your samples and/or data are studied as part of this research, there are different types of results that could be returned to you
Like we mentioned earlier, you are being referred to this study because you or your family member has a known or suspected genetic condition based on specific health issues
Right
This PMGRC study will try to find genetic changes that may be related to those issues
These results are called primary findings, and they often allow the clinical team to make a diagnosis
Later in this chat, you will get to choose whether you want to be told about these primary findings
Great!
Sometimes the study may find genetic variants that are not related to the patient’s current known health issues
These results are called secondary findings

Some of these secondary findings are considered medically actionable, meaning if these genetic changes are known, then you or your healthcare provider can then take action to try and reduce your risk of developing the health problems or to better treat or manage the health problems
What kind of findings are medically actionable?
Some examples of medically actionable secondary findings may be genetic variants that cause increased risk for future health issues like heart disease or cancer
Secondary findings are often related to adult health risks, but it is possible that we could discover a secondary finding that relates to health issues in childhood
Okay, I understand
Knowing about a medically actionable genetic variant allows doctors to adjust your medical care plan
This can include avoiding certain medications or more frequent checkups with your doctor
That's good to know

The study could also discover secondary findings are not medically actionable, meaning they could be related to an increased risk for certain diseases for which there are no known treatments or medical actions
I'll keep that in mind
It’s important to note that our research team will not be analyzing every sample for secondary findings, but it is possible that we will identify secondary findings in the course of the study
What if I don’t want to know about those kinds of health risks?
That’s perfectly fine

If you do decide to participate in the study, you will get to decide if you want to receive any possible research results.  And you can decide if you want to receive some types of results and not others
That's good to know
Sometimes genetic testing can find unexpected or surprising results that aren’t related to the genetic health issues in your family
For example, sometimes genetic testing can reveal that a child's parent is not actually their biological parent or that two parents are related to each other by blood
These types of unexpected results are called incidental findings
Oh, okay
We do not plan to go looking for these types of incidental findings and we don’t plan to tell you about them
But it is possible that you could figure out these incidental results based on other genetic test results we may share with you
I understand
If the study team finds a genetic change that relates to genetic health issues, we plan to tell you about it if you have opted to receive that kind of research result
However, because the results from our study are research results (not clinical results), we will not provide you with an official clinical report
And you should know that any research findings will need to be confirmed in a certified clinical lab before they can be added to your medical record
Who will pay for that testing?
What does "confirmed in a clinical lab" mean?
You or your insurance company will have to pay for those additional services
Got it
Most tests done on samples in research studies are only for research and have no clear meaning for healthcare
If we think that there are research results that might have meaning for you or your family, these tests should be re-done by a certified clinical laboratory
Results will only be placed in your medical record once they have been clinically confirmed
I understand
Just so you know, we expect this PMGRC study to last at least until 2026, but you can choose to stop participating at any time
After signing the Consent/Authorization, you can change your mind and either revoke or withdraw your authorization in the future
Good to know!
To revoke the Authorization, you must send a written letter to the Principal Investigator to inform him of your decision

Seth Berger, MD, PhD
Children's National Research and Innovation Campus
7144 13th Place NW
Washington, DC 20012
If you revoke this Authorization, researchers may only use and disclose the PHI that was collected for this research study before you revoked the Authorization
If you change your mind and withdraw the Authorization, you will not be allowed to participate in the study
I understand

It is important that you know that anyone who undergoes genetic testing in the United States is protected from certain types of discrimination by a United States federal law called the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act (GINA)
What areas are protected?
Generally, GINA makes it illegal for health insurance companies, group health insurance plans, and most employers to discriminate against you based on your genetic information
However, this does not apply to companies with fewer than 15 employees or the United States military
How is health insurance protected?
How are employers involved?
I understand
Health insurance companies may not request your genetic information that we get from this research
Health insurance companies may not use your genetic information when deciding whether to insure you or the amount of money they will charge you
I understand
Employers may not use your genetic information that we get from this research when deciding to hire, promote, or fire you
I understand
It’s also very important to know that GINA does not protect you against genetic discrimination by companies that sell life insurance, disability insurance, or long-term care insurance
What does that mean?
Do I need to worry about this?
Okay

These kinds of additional insurance companies (such as life insurance or disability insurance) might ask you to provide your medical history–including genetic testing results–before allowing you to enroll
Because the genetic testing being done in this study is for research only, the results will not be part of any official medical record until they are confirmed by a clinical lab.
Some families may choose to enroll in these kinds of insurances for their child or themselves before getting a clinically validated genetic test result
Okay
Because the genetic testing being done in this study is for research only, the results will not be part of any official medical record until they are confirmed by a clinical lab
Some families may choose to enroll in these kinds of insurances for their child or themselves before getting a clinically-validated genetic test result
Okay
I’d like to take a moment to give you some info about the risks and possible discomforts that may occur as part of participating in this study

The greatest risks of this study are related to sample collection, the potential for loss of confidentiality of your study information, and possible psychological risks associated with genetic information
That may sound like a lot, so I will go through each of these with you
Okay, Mia 👍
There are some risks related to taking the blood sample, such as discomfort and/or bruising
Infection, excess bleeding, clotting, or fainting can happen
There may be minimal discomfort in the cheek if a cheek swab sample is obtained
Okay, I understand
The study team will take care to protect the privacy and confidentiality of your study data
Because your samples and data will be labeled only with a study ID, your personal information (like your name) will only be known to certain authorized study team members
The team will keep your personal and genetic data on a secure drive, and you will be notified immediately if there is a security breach
That's good to know
However, even though your samples and data will not be labeled with your name or other personal information, your genetic information is unique to you
So it is possible that someone could identify you from your genetic information or learn something about you by looking at your genetic information
This risk may increase in the future as technologies advance and as more researchers study your genetic information
Ah, I see
That is concerning
These risks may also affect members of your family
You may want to discuss your participation in this study with your family and ask the study team about any questions or concerns you may have
Okay, I'll keep that in mind
There can also be some risks associated with learning about genetic results that may be discovered through this study
Genetic testing can sometimes reveal results that you were not expecting or even things you do not want to know
It is possible that learning about your genetic results may make you feel distressed or anxious
Ah, okay
Some results may be more certain than others
For example, sometimes we may find a “variant of uncertain significance”, which means that we aren’t sure whether the genetic variant is linked to a specific health issue or not
Some people may feel anxious or uncomfortable about uncertain results
Okay
And finally, results from this study may sometimes give you information about a genetic health issue that does not have a clear medical treatment
Some people may feel distressed or anxious to learn about a genetic health issue or risk without a known treatment
It is up to you to decide if you want to receive any possible genetic results from this study, and you can also decide if you want to receive some types of results but not others
That's good to know
We can also talk a little bit about the possible benefits of participating in this study
You should know that there may be no benefit to you for your participation in this study, and you will not be paid for your participation in this study
Okay, I understand
Some study participants may benefit by getting a new genetic diagnosis or discovering the genetic cause of a known genetic health issue
